answers.a: NaDS (sodium dodecyl sulfate, E487) is used in some foods as an anionic surfactant—primarily as a foaming/whipping agent, emulsifier, and wetting agent; it’s more commonly found in personal-care and cleaning products.
It lowers surface tension so ingredients mix and foam more easily, helping disperse fats and improve whipping volume and texture in certain foods.
Creating and stabilizing foam, aiding emulsification, and improving wetting/dispersion of powders or oils in food formulations.
NaDS stands for sodium dodecyl sulfate (also called sodium lauryl sulfate), the food additive E487.
There isn’t a NaDS supplement—it's not a nutrient; when present, NaDS is used as a technological food additive (surfactant), not for health benefits.
Sodium lauryl sulfate (E487) is widely used and considered safe at regulated levels, but it can irritate skin and mucous membranes in some people.

answers.q: does sensodyne have sodium lauryl sulfate
answers.a: Many Sensodyne toothpastes are SLS-free, but formulations vary by product and market—check the ingredient list for “sodium lauryl sulfate” to be sure.

answers.q: is sodium lauryl sulfate bad for hair
answers.a: It isn’t inherently harmful to hair, but as a strong cleanser SLS can strip oils and irritate sensitive or color-treated hair and scalps.

answers.q: what toothpaste does not have sodium lauryl sulfate
answers.a: SLS-free options include Biotene, many Sensodyne variants, Tom’s of Maine SLS-free lines, Hello, and Zendium (availability varies by market); always confirm on the ingredient list.

answers.q: does sodium lauryl sulfate cause hair loss
answers.a: There’s no good evidence that SLS directly causes hair loss, though scalp irritation in sensitive users could contribute to dryness, breakage, or temporary shedding.
